title: Great Central Walk Rugby Route

images.title: Andy F / Looking north along trackbed of ex-Great Central Railway, Rugby
images.caption: Looking north along trackbed of ex-Great Central Railway, Rugby

images.title: Ian Rob / Rugby-Great Central Walk
images.caption: The huge three arch bridge over the deep railway cutting at Ashlawn Road.

images.title: Ian Rob / Rugby-Lower Rainsbrook
images.caption: The dismantled bridge for the Great Central Railway over the road to Lower Rainsbrook Farm from Onley Lane.

images.title: Stephen McKay / Pytchley Road Bridge, Rugby
images.caption: This bridge provides pedestrian access between Pytchley Road, on the Southfields Estate, and Percival Road, on the Ashlawn Estate, across the former Great Central railway. This saves pedestrians a considerable detour.

images.title: Great Central Walk at Onley Lane by Stephen McKay, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons

images.title: Robert Eva / Old platform remains
images.caption: Old platform remains. Part of the old Rugby Central station platform still discernible through the vegetation.

images.title: Ian Rob / Rugby-Great Central Walk
images.caption: The Clifton Road Bridge in the foreground, and Bridge Street Bridge in the distance.

images.title: Nature Reserve, Rugby, Warwickshire by Graham Hogg, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Trail view with bridge.

description: This walk takes you along the Great Central Walk in the Warwickshire town of Rugby. The dismantled railway line is now a nature reserve which is open to walkers and cyclists. The trail can be picked up just to the south of Rugby train station and followed for just over 3 miles to Onley Lane. Here you leave the trail to follow the country lane down to the Oxford Canal at the southern end. The area is good for wildlife spotting with a variety of butterflies and birds to see along the path. At the end of the route you can extend your walk by picking up the towpath of the canal and following it north to take you back to Rugby. See our Circular Walk Around Rugby for more details. If you head south it along the canal it will take you into Braunston. Just to the west of the walk you will find the lovely Draycote Water where there's a nice waterside footpath to follow around the lake.
